questions.answer_description:
Site Recovery is used to manage and orchestrate disaster recovery of on-premises machines and Azure VMs. However, it can also be used for migration.
Migration uses the same steps as disaster recovery with one exception. In a migration, failing machines over from your on-premises site is the final step. Unlike disaster recovery, you can't fail back to on-premises in a migration scenario.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/migrate-tutorial-on-premises-azure
questions.question_text:
You plan to migrate an SAP environment to Azure.
You need to recommend a solution to migrate the SAP application servers to Azure. The solution must minimize downtime and changes to the environments.
What should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content: ASR can be used to SAP Application migration, but it cant be used for DB migration.
The answer is right: https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/itshowcase/strategies-for-migrating-sap-systems-to-microsoft-azure

Selected Answer: D
correct
Minimizes Downtime is key in the question so Azure site recovery
I will go with ASR
ASR is an alternative here.
No best choice - other than ASR..can someobe confirm ?
Question specifically mentions "SAP Application server" so my pick will be ASR
ASR can be used as migration purpose, too.

Azure site recovery is not recommended for migration as per the below link , which says. 
 ""Site Recovery should be used for disaster recovery only, and not migration."" 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/site-recovery/migrate-tutorial-on-premises-azure

Does anyone know correct answer

comments.content:
For Application Servers, it is a correct option for migration. The url you posted also says the following " If you're already using Azure Site Recovery, and you want to continue using it for migration, follow the same steps that you use for disaster recovery." 

So it is not about not supported for DR only.

questions.question_text:
You plan to migrate an on-premises SAP development system to Azure.
Before the migration, you need to check the usage of the source system hardware, such as CPU, memory, network, etc.
Which transaction should you run from SAP GUI?
questions.answer_description:
SAP transaction OS07N (Remote Operating System Activity) is classified in the Basis Component module under application component Operating System
Monitors and runs Monitoring Operating System program RSHOST1N upon execution.
Incorrect Answers:
A: Transaction code SM51 is to display list of active application servers that have registered in the SAP message server.
B: DB01 is a transaction code used for Analyze Exclusive Lockwaits in SAP.
C: Transaction code DB12 is to collects and presents information that is necessary to monitor database backups.
References:
http://www.saptransactions.com/codes/OS07N/

discussion.content: Ans: OS07N
OS07N (old systems ST06)

Selected Answer: D
correct
D. OS07N
OS07N IS THE RIGHT ANSWER

questions.answer_description:
The SAP Cloud Platform Identity Authentication and Active Directory Federation Services enable you to implement SSO across applications or services that are protected by Azure AD (as an IdP) with SAP applications and services that are protected by SAP Cloud Platform Identity Authentication.
Scenario: Use Active Directory accounts to administer Azure resources.
Incorrect Answers:
Not D: With Windows 10, Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) users gain the ability to securely synchronize their user settings and application settings data to the cloud. Enterprise State Roaming provides users with a unified experience across their Windows devices and reduces the time needed for configuring a new device. Enterprise State Roaming operates similar to the standard consumer settings sync that was first introduced in Windows 8.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/saas-apps/sap-hana-cloud-platform-identity-authentication-tutorial

discussion.content: B, use AD connect to sync on-premise AD accounts to Azure AD to manage and administer Azure resources, one of the technical requirements

The correct answer is B: AD connect, it's not mandatory to have AD FS, you can use Password HAsh Synch or Passthrough Authentication, but AD Connect is mandatory to synch you on-promises accounts to Azure AD

In this question I was in doubt between letter A and B.
I think it's the letter "A" anyway...
I agree B

questions.question_text:
This question requires that you evaluate the underlined text to determine if it is correct.
You are planning for the administration of resources in Azure.
To meet the technical requirements, you must first implement Active Directory Federation Services (AD FS).
Instructions: Review the underlined text. If it makes the statement correct, select `No change is needed`. If the statement is incorrect, select the answer choice that makes the statement correct.

HOTSPOT -
Before putting the SAP environment on Azure into production, which command should you run to ensure that the virtual machine disks meet the business requirements? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Scenario: Ensure that all the production databases can withstand the failure of an Azure region.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.compute/get-azvmimage

discussion.content: both answers incorrect. Get-AzDisk is used to check disk type. SAP on Azure for prod deployments should use Managed Premium disks only and not Standard ones for database

1. get-azdisk
Get-AzDisk
 [[-ResourceGroupName] <String>]
 [[-DiskName] <String>]
 [-DefaultProfile <IAzureContextContainer>]
 [<CommonParameters>]

2. 
Business requirement - Ensure that all the production databases can withstand the failure of an Azure region.
Hence Standard_RAGRS - Standard Read-Access Geo Replicated Storage

get-azdisk
premiumLRS
Get-AzDisk is correct because the disk are stored in storage account and it is the one that gets replication e.g. LRS or GRS etc. It is not the VM which gets replicated.
what is -ne in the where clause?

comments.content: I'm sorry, the next answer should be Standard RA-GRS, because of the Business requirement - "Ensure that all the production databases can withstand the failure of an Azure region."

I want to share the information below to support my answer:
The type of Standard_RAGRS is for unmanaged disk, according to the template, the disks are managed disks, and Managed disks are only available for Locally Redundant Storage (LRS).
https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/pricing/details/managed-disks/

I want to correct the second answer again, the correct answer should be "Primium_LRS".
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/planning-guide-storage#azure-standard-ssd-storage
and we should recommend another solution to meet the Business requirement - "Ensure that all the production databases can withstand the failure of an Azure region."

discussion.content:
The command Get-AZVMimage has not parameter "-ResourceGroupName" and the object(VMImage) that returned from the command Get-AZVMimage has not sku property but skus(like "2012-R2-Datacenter"). so the answers given are wrong. the correct answers should be Get-AzDisk & Primium_LRS.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.compute/get-azvmimage?view=azps-4.6.1
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.compute/get-azdisk?view=azps-4.6.1
Get-AzDisk and Premium_LRS. These allow to verify the requirement for Production Systems.

comments.content: nice, with this command of yours we get vms that have notsupported disks what is exactly we need
but Get-AzDisk and Premium_LRS with -ne option means we get list of disk all but Premium_LRS type, so it is not supported for prod sap env

discussion.content: from script it is clearly mentioned that the creation of disk should be from the image so Get-AZVMimage is appropriate and where the requirement is that the production should be protected from failure of a region only disk that support it are standard_RAGRS

comments.content:
Get-AZVMimage have not the parameter SKU refering to the disk, it concerns the image for OS, see the link
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.compute/get-azvmimage?view=azps-5.2.0#example-1--get-vmimage-objects

discussion.content:
Business requirement is that the solution should be supported by SAP.
Standard disks for Prod are not supported.
Answer is Get-AZDisk and Premium_LRS
Production databases can withstand the failure of an Azure region this is business requirement. so Standard_RAGRS is correct.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.compute/?view=azps-4.3.0#vm_disks
Get-AzDisk & Primary SSD due to PRod workload

comments.content:
I agree with Premium_LRS, because it is for production application servers.
Please refer to :
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/workloads/sap/planning-guide-storage#azure-standard-ssd-storage

discussion.content:
Answer should be - Premium_LRS

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/compute/disks/createorupdate

Name Type Description
Premium_LRS 

Premium SSD locally redundant storage. Best for production and performance sensitive workloads.

StandardSSD_LRS 

Standard SSD locally redundant storage. Best for web servers, lightly used enterprise applications and dev/test.

Standard_LRS 

Standard HDD locally redundant storage. Best for backup, non-critical, and infrequent access.
4\premiumLRS\contoso.com

Standard_LRS is the traditional HDD. Not to confuse with StandardSSD_LRS which is not even listed. I don't think it is recommended to use a traditional HDD. So Premium_LRS is the correct one.
contoso.onmicrosoft.com is a tenant domain name but there is no information about the tenant name. But the company uses Contoso.com for the email, and that domain needs to be added and verified to the tenant domains for AD connect sync. So contoso.com is correct.

4 disks - to choose so " 4 "
Geo redundancy - GRS
domain same as mentioned

comments.content: where in template provided can we see "ad.contoso.com"?

discussion.content: The domainName should be ad.contoso.com, as mentionned in the template "JoinDomain" parameter, you need to specify the AD DS not Azure AD domain.
The config looks to be an OS disk , hence its Standard_LRS I think

Standard_GRS should be the appropriate answer. As you have to meet all below business requirements.
- Minimize costs whenever possible.
- Ensure that all SAP deployments to Azure are supported by SAP.
- Ensure that all the production databases can withstand the failure of an Azure region.

comments.content: never mind. It is a requirement in the text. But I do not understand why it is needed for an application server

discussion.content: Why 4 disks of 1 TB for a SAP application server?

Business goal says - Ensure that all SAP deployments to Azure are supported by SAP, so the storage account type should be 'Premium_LRS' since it is for PROD App servers.

Also as of Feb 2020 there are several limitations added for the kind of storage types used for SAP workloads on Azure, refer to SAP note 2015553.

comments.content: See the question- it’s asking for application server and not for HANA Database server. ——>Azure Resource Manager template that will be used to provision the “production application servers.“<—

discussion.content: SAP HANA does not support Standard. It should be Premium_LRS

comments.content: If StandardSSD_LRS is one of the options then it's suitable as an answer, according to MSFT : Microsoft recommends using Azure Standard SSD storage as minimum for Azure VMs hosting the SAP application layer and for non-performance sensitive DBMS deployment and using Azure Premium SSD storage for all other Azure VMs DBMS workloads.

My answer below is wrong - I chose 'Premium_LRS' earlier but then got it clarified.

There are several VM series like Dv2-series, Dv3-series, Ev3-series, G-series which can use only Standard storage account type and supported by SAP to host SAP NetWeaver (A)SCS and SAP NetWeaver application server/dialog instances only. So the option "StandardSSD_LRS" holds good in this case since it is for SAP App server even though it is meant for Production.

discussion.content: It's for production so it should be Premium_LRS

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You need to provide the Azure administrator with the values to complete the Azure Resource Manager template.
Which values should you provide for diskCount, StorageAccountType, and domainName? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
Box 1: 4 -
Scenario: the Azure Resource Manager template that will be used to provision the production application servers.
Ensure that each production application server has four 1-TB data disks.

Box 2: Standard_ZRS -
Scenario: Minimize costs whenever possible.

Box 3: contoso.onmicrosoft.com -
The network contains an on-premises Active Directory domain named ad.contoso.com.
The Initial domain: The default domain (onmicrosoft.com) in the Azure AD Tenant. For example, contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/hybrid/plan-connect-userprincipalname https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/pricing/details/managed-disks/
